page.title: 08RECREATION - DERWENT VALLEY
page.content: The Derwent Walk Country Park is of major significance as a leisure resource, though at present under developed and under used. It replaces the route of the original railway line both passenger and freight, from Consett to Newcastle. In full swing, the railway carried coal to the Tyne and even then the valley was a popular beauty spot. The walk is 'single line' in width and almost all viaducts, bridges and cuttings have been retained and maintained with the exception of 2 bridges over the B6310 Burnopfield to Hamsterley Mill and the Longclose Bank, Hamsterley Mill to Medomsley, roads, which have now been demolished. Though the surface and verges of the Walk are adequately maintained, little attempt has been made to introduce new flora by the way of improvement.
